This will be Damaris’ first loan with KADET LTD, and she plans to use the entire loan to purchase soil and polythene bags for her mushroom business. She plans to reinvest the profit into the business. 

In the future, she wants to be a prosperous business woman.

loans.use: to purchase polythene bags and soil for planting mushrooms.

loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en:
Mrs. Tserendolgor is a 46-year-old woman who lives with her husband and three children in a Ger (Mongolian yurt) in Hovd province of Mongolia. Her husband Purevdorj, age of 50, works as driver in a private company. Her two older children, Naranchimeg and Bathuyag, are university students, and her daughter Monhtsetseg is a secondary school student. 

Tserendolgor has been breeding cattle and producing organic dairy products out of the organic milk she produces. She is planning to expand her business and purchase large amounts of milk to produce more organic dairy products to sell during the winter to local customers.

She is now requesting a loan of 2,000,000 Mongolian tughriks (MNT) to purchase a large amount of milk for producing organic dairy products to sell to local customers during the winter. She is a hardworking and diligent woman.

loans.use: to purchase large amount of milk for producing organic dairy products to sell to local customers during the winter.

loans.name: Agustin

texts.en: Agustin wants to thank all Kiva lenders for the previous loan, which allowed him to buy the milk cow.  Now he is requesting a new loan in order to build two separate stables, one for cows and one for goats.   Agustin hopes that the livestock business he has begun will go as planned and that, with the profit, he will be able to provide for his parents and create his own family soon.

loans.use: to build two separate stables for cows and goats.

loans.name: Jose Galo

texts.es:
José es un hombre de 54 años cursó la educación secundaria para luego convertirse en comerciante, está casado con Susana de 51 años, tienen 3 hijos ya adultos de 34, 32 y 21 años. Vive con su esposa en el sur de la ciudad de Quito capital de la República del Ecuador, específicamente en el barrio de Chimbacalle un barrio muy emblemático de Quito principalmente por ser la morada de la única Estación de trenes de la capital la cual se convertirá en un museo ferroviario que a la par con los museos de su alrededor se ha convertido en uno de los lugares turísticos más visitados del país. Sumado a este atractivo, en general, el sector sur de la ciudad de Quito en los últimos años se ha desarrollado notablemente tanto urbana y económicamente, es así que inversionistas han apostado para sembrar sus ideas en varios puntos clave de este sector. La competencia para microempresarios es muy fuerte, pues se puede encontrar negocios de todo tipo en cada paso.  Chimbacalle alberga grandes historias de hombres y mujeres luchadoras que han encontrado en este lugar alto de la ciudad, la oportunidad de ver sus sueños cumplidos y además de ser parte del crecimiento de este sector de la ciudad. 
José se ha dedicado a comercializar verduras y frutas desde hace 15 años, cuando aprendió de un gran amigo de la Costa ecuatoriana a quien le ayudaba en esta actividad. No recibe ayuda de personas adicionales, solo en su local trabaja al menos 8 horas diarias. Muchas veces no puede abastecer los pedidos de sus clientes porque no cuenta con los productos solicitados. Sin embargo con su experiencia, él afirma que sus ingresos mejorarían si invierte en surtir sus productos. Por esta razón, José acudió a Fundación Alternativa para solicitar un crédito con el cual pueda hacer realidad esta idea. José espera que invirtiendo este dinero y poniendo en práctica la asesoría que su ejecutivo le brinda con herramientas para la buena administración de su negocio; él pueda incrementar la utilidad de su negocio para tener un ahorro que en el futuro le permita adquirir un camión para distribuir al por mayor a otros sectores de la ciudad y de la provincia. José agradece la intermediación de Kiva para que varias personas alrededor del mundo participen en el cumplimiento de sus sueños.
texts.en:
José is a 54-year-old man who studied secondary education but later became a merchant.  He is married to Susana who is 51 years old.  They have three adult children who are 34, 32 and 21 years old.  He lives with his wife in the south of the city of Quito, the capital of the Republic of Ecuador, specifically in the neighborhood of Chimbacalle, a very emblematic neighborhood of Quito.  This is mainly because it is the dwelling place of the only train station in the capital which will be converted into a railway museum that, on par with the surrounding museums, has become one of the most visited tourist places in the country.  Together with this attraction, in general, the southern sector of the city of Quito in recent years has developed considerably, both in an urban and economic sense.  So investors have positioned themselves to sow their plans in several key places in this sector.  The competition for small-businessmen is very strong, as one can find all kinds of businesses at every step.  Chimbacalle harbors great stories of fighting men and women who have found in this high place in the city the opportunity to see their dreams fulfilled and also to be part of the growth of this area of the city.

José has made a living selling vegetables and fruits for 15 years from the time when he learned from a great friend from the Ecuadoran coast who was helping him in this activity.  He doesn’t receive any help from additional people, he works alone in his business location at least 8 hours a day.  Many times he can’t supply the orders of his customers because he doesn’t have the requested products.  However, with his experience he states that his income would improve if he invests in stocking up on his products.  For this reason José turned to Fundación Alternativa to request a loan with which he can make this idea a reality.  José hopes that by investing this money and putting into practice the advice that his manager provides him with the tools for good administration of his business, he can increase the utility of his business to have a savings that in the future will allow him to purchase a truck to distribute wholesale to other sectors of the city and of the province.  José is grateful for the intermediation of Kiva so that various people around the world participate in the fulfillment of his dreams.

loans.use: to buy fruits, vegetables and legumes to stock his business.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is 40 years old, married and blessed with 5 children, ages 5, 8, 10, 12 and 15 years. Samson is a retail trader who sells industrial goods in Muhoroni. His business has been in operation for the past 2 years, earning an income of 10,000 KES.  

He has borrowed a loan of 30,000 KES from KADET LTD. This is his third loan term, and he wishes to use this amount to purchase sugar, rice and baking flour to resell. The profits earned will be reinvested in the business.  

He hopes to open a supermarket in the near future and to educate his children to the highest level possible.

loans.use: to purchase stock for his retail shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy manure for her coffee plantation.

loans.name: C80703 Dufatanyiterambere Group

texts.en:
Celestin is 48 years old.  He is married with three children between the ages of 10 and 23 years.  He is a butcher and he sells meat in his business, which is well organized.  He works from 6 AM until 6 PM every day of the week.  He has two years of experience in this work and employs four people to help him.

Celestin is the leader of the group, which is called “C80703 DUFATANYITERAMBERE” in the local language, and he is pictured above in the middle with a paper in his hand.  He has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase a greater quantity of meat to resell. 

With the profits he earns, he plans to save money for his future and to pay his children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase meat to resell.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is 32 years old.  He is married and has three children.  

He has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 UGX in order to buy 500 chicks for his poultry farm.  Godfrey hopes that, after four months, they will be mature enough to begin laying eggs.  He plans to plough the profits back into his business and expand his poultry farm.  In addition, Godfrey plans to complete his unfinished house and also to buy tree seedlings and plant pine trees on his plantation.  He is targeting to have a farm of over 1,000 birds by the end of 2013.

loans.use: to buy chicks for his poultry farm.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is Fatmata. She is single and has three children. In 2011, Fatmata established her medical service business. She began her business because she wants to render medical service to her community to reduce their suffering. Her business is located in a city center, and her main customers are people from the community. Working seven days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about SLL 8,493,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Fatmata requires a loan in order to buy pharmaceutical drugs, cough mixtures and IV drips. Fatmata plans to open up a community health center in the future. The loan will be used to further expand her pharmacy. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more medicines

loans.name: Urgats

texts.en:
Mrs. Urgats is 52 years old and lives with her daughter and son, in a house in Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her son, Battsolmon, age 24, graduated from university this June and stays home looking for a job now. Her daughter, Batchimeg, age 21, is a university student. 

Urgats has been working as a tailor for a private tailoring company for 15 years. Now she is planning to start her own business at home, in the spare room of her house. She is requesting 3,000,000MNT to purchase equipment and inventory, to start her new business of tailoring. She is an honest and diligent woman.

loans.use: to purchase equipment and inventory, to start her new business of tailoring

loans.name: Alinyikira Group

texts.en:
At 28 years of age, Amina is married and has two kids. She also looks after her four sisters, who are dependent on her for their livelihood because they are orphans. She sells charcoal stoves made of clay to meet her needs and those of her extended family. Her main challenge is customers who take stoves on credit and fail to pay back. 

She dreams of buying a plot of land in the future, using savings from her business. She was excited about joining the borrowing group because this will help her increase her working capital, which in turn will reduce the strain on the limited resources. She is very hard-working and persevering, despite the challenges of supporting her extended family. Amina is the lady in white and black at the front row on the right.

loans.use: To buy local charcoal stoves, made of clay, to resell.

loans.name: Isata

texts.en:
This is 45 year old Isatu.  She is a widow and has two children, ages 17 and 15. She has 2 additional dependents, living with her as sales assistants.  

In 2004, Isatu established her charcoal and palm oil business. She began her business because there was no help for her when she lost her husband. Her business is located in the central market, and her main customers are women. Working 7 days a week, 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 800,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000, which she will use to purchase 100 bags of charcoal for resale. She hopes this loan will help her get more customers, and more profit.

In the future, Isatu plans to educate her children and get a house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal and palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is 45 years old. He is married and has four children. He and his wife earn their income through the sale of crops and livestock. They grow maize, beans, coffee, cassava, bananas, sunflowers, and eggplant. They also have pigs, goats, and chickens. 

Christopher looks forward to becoming a Community Knowledge Worker (CKW). As a CKW he will use the materials in his business-in-a-box (smartphone, solar charging set, and weighing scale) to disseminate vital agricultural information to the other members of his village, helping them to improve their crop yields and increase their incomes.  

With the additional money that he will earn as a CKW, Christopher will save up to buy more land.

loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone, solar charging set, and weighing scale so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Roselyne

texts.en:
Roselyne, a courageous mother of four, has been a small business operator in the Mukuru informal settlement of Nairobi, Kenya for many years.  Roselyne is also a trained community mobilizer. She has gained invaluable business experience both from running her own businesses as well as working for other people. However, she had to stop running her businesses and quit her job due to health problems.

A Fresh Life Toilet will give Roselyne the opportunity to generate extra income for her family. She foresees that the amount of effort needed to run this business is manageable with her health problems.

Roselyne hopes to use the profits to add more Fresh Life Toilets within her community, as well as educate her children to the highest level possible.

loans.use: to purchase and run one Fresh Life Toilet.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy seasonal coats, pants, and blouses in order to supply his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more goats and cows to resell.

loans.name: Sorie

texts.en:
This is 39 year old Sorie.  He is married and has two children, ages 5 & 10. He has 1 additional dependent, who is living with him because of school.  

In 1997, Sorie established his sand business. His business is located on the outskirts of town, and his main customers are building construction men. 

Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 800,000 monthly from this business. He would like a loan of Le 4,000,000, with which he plans to purchase a 25kva horse power outboard motor to be use to transport his sand for resale. 

He hopes that this loan will help simplify faster transportation of the sand, so he can realize a huge profit. 

In the future, Sorie plans to build, and educate his children to the university level. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy a 25kva horse power motor to transport sand for his business.

loans.name: Bina

texts.en:
Bina is 45 years old. She is married and has three children aged 11, 14, and 22. In 2000 she established her vegetable farming business. Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family.

Bina has already received and successfully repaid six loans from Patan BPW. She will use her most recent loan to buy seeds and fertilizers.

In the future, Bina plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers for her vegetable farm.

loans.name: Benitor

texts.en:
Benitor is 43 years old and lives in the community of Congo Town called Vai Town. She is a mother of three children and is married. Benitor stopped her education in the 12th grade. Her children are between the ages of 13 and 20 and attend school. 

She has been involved in the sales of rice, butter, flour, sugar, milk, and cooking oil for the past five years. She makes a profit when she sells, and with the profit she buys more goods to improve the business. The profits also help with the expenses of the family. 

Benitor is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, butter, sugar, flour, and milk for the business. She hopes to become a big business woman.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, butter, sugar, flour, and milk for her business,

loans.name: Nisha

texts.en:
Nisha is 24 years old. She is married and has two children ages 1 and 5. In 2010 she established her grocery store business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family.  

Nisha has already received and successfully repaid one loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buys grocery goods for her business.  

In the future, Nisa plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called a pasal, are an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buys grocery goods for her business.

loans.name: Parbati

texts.en:
Parbati is thirty-eight years old. She is married and has two children, ages seventeen and twenty. In 2006, she established her tailoring business.  Working six days a week and ten hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buy raw materials for her business. In the future, Parbati plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailor stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines. These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. With a Kiva loan, BPW borrowers are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines to increase production and profitability.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
This is Daniel. He is a business owner in his hometown of Livingstone, Zambia. This is his story..

My name is Daniel. I am 30 years old and I have a daughter. I run an Internet café and mobile money transfer shop in my hometown of Livingstone. I need the loan so that I can increase my mobile money transfer working capital.

I enjoy running my own business, because I have the freedom to make decisions, and get to meet a lot of people. I have always wanted to run my own business, so in the year 2004 I quit my job and invested in the Internet café. My community benefits from my business because they can come to my shop to send and receive money at cheap rates. They also come in to stay up-to-date with what is happening in the world by browsing on the Internet.

When I get this loan, I believe my business will change for the better because I will be able to serve more customers who want to send money. An increase in my working capital will mean I get to make more profits. This will change my life because it will make providing for my daughter much easier.

loans.use: To have more people send and receive money from his shop so that he can earn more profits

loans.name: Dan

texts.en:
Dan is fifty years old and lives in the town of Gaba, in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has six children. Dan has been working hard to manage his butcher shop where he sells meat. 

To help expand his business, Dan has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy other kinds of meats during the festive season. It will help Dan to generate greater profits and enable him to make more profits. Dan hopes that, in the future, he will be able to have a quality butcher shop in his area. 

Dan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Dan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more meat for resale.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kintintale in the Kampala South region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. Lydia has been working hard to manage her electronic store, which deals in all kinds of electronics. 

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to expand her business and buy more electronic items, which will help Lydia generate greater profits and increase her daily sales.  Lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to purchase the electronics from China herself. 

Lydia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lydia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to expand her business and buy more electronic items.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.es:
Jenny, de 31 años, es una señora muy amable, trabajadora y muy valiente, es madre soltera de tres hijos de 18, 16 y 13 años a quienes cría sola y son su razón de esfuerzo y sacrificio, no tiene ningún problema en afrontar esta difícil situación y vive día a día con optimismo, habita junto a sus hijos en la casa de su padre luchando para salir adelante. El trabajo de Jenny consiste en la venta de comida, sale todos los días a la vereda de su casa en donde por las mañana vende desayunos conformado por jugos de frutas y panes con algún contenido nutritivo y por las noches ofrece a la venta algunas carnes asadas y comidas regionales, todo su trabajo lo realiza en su casa. Lleva trabajando ahí por al menos 10 años, en algunas ocasiones recibe la ayuda de sus hijos. Se inició vendiendo solo desayunos y con el tiempo fue implementando su negocio con mayor variedad de potajes.
Le agrada mucho lo que hace, le encanta cocinar y siempre esta a la expectativa de brindar lo mejor a sus clientes, además de trabajar con su negocio, ella en algunas ocasiones trabaja en una cebicheria, en donde brinda sus servicios de cocinera y por ello recibe un pago adicional que significa un ingreso mas a su economía, espera poner su propio restaurante con el paso del tiempo. Este es el préstamo número 6 con MFP, está muy agradecida por la oportunidad crediticia que le brindan y por el respaldo financiero que necesita para seguir adelante. Se compromete a pagar sus cuotas mensuales de manera puntual y continuar trabajando con mucha responsabilidad junto a los miembros de su banco comunal. 
Con el monto solicitado 2500 soles, comprará 4 mesas y sillas para implementar su negocio de ventas, además comprará ingredientes e insumos como arroz, carnes, azúcar, verduras, tubérculos, aceites, condimentos y otros productos que le permitan seguir preparando los deliciosos potajes que pone a la venta.
texts.en:
Jenny, 31, is a very kind, hardworking, brave lady.  She’s a single mother of three children who are 18, 16 and 13 years of age who she raises alone and are the reason for all her efforts and sacrifice.  She has no problem facing this difficult situation and lives day to day with optimism.  She lives in her father’s house with her children striving to get ahead.  Jenny’s work consists in selling food.  She goes out to her sidewalk every day and sells breakfast consisting in fruit juice and bread rolls with some nutritional value in the morning and at night sells grilled meats and regional dishes.  She does all her work at home.  She’s been working for at least ten years and her children help sometimes.  She started out just selling breakfast and in time started to add a greater variety of dishes to her business.

She likes what she does very much.  She loves to cook and is always ready to provide the best to her customers.  In addition to working with her business she sometimes also works for a marinated fish shop as a cook and earns a salary that way which means extra income for her family.  She hopes in time to open her own restaurant.

This is loan #6 with MFP and she’s very grateful for the loan opportunity she’s being given and for the financial back-up she needs to continue moving forward.  She commits to make her monthly payments punctually and to continue working very responsibly with her fellow communal bank members.

She will use the requested 2,500 soles to buy four tables and chairs to furnish her food sales business and she will also buy ingredients like rice, meats, sugar, vegetables, tubers, oil, condiments and others to continue making the delicious dishes she sells.

loans.use: to buy rice, meat, sugar, vegetables, tubers, oil and condiments.

loans.name: Hani

texts.en:
Hani is a 22-year-old man. He is Lebanese and single. He lives with his parent and two siblings, one of whom is working. His brother is supporting him, especially after finding it hard to cover the usual family expenses. 

Hani has owned a cattle farm in his town, where he raised cattle from which he obtained dairy products. He has been involved in this domain for many years; he knows very well how to manage his work in a good way. He’s really good in his domain and looks forward to developing his business as much as he possibly can. 

For this reason, he wanted to take a youth loan form Kiva Partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase added cattle for his farm. In his opinion, this step will allow him to increase his productivity, therefore his earnings, and thus his whole way of living. Because of his good products, Hani thinks he will open a small shop where he will sell all kinds of dairy products.

loans.use: to purchase added cattle for his farm.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 40 years old. She is married and has ten children. She and her husband earn their income through farming. They grow maize, beans, cassava, vegetables, avocados and coffee. They also keep cows, goats and chickens. They also earn money from the small commodities shop that they have, as well as through daily labor jobs that they perform for others in the community.

Rehema looks forward to becoming a Community Knowledge Worker (CKW). As a CKW, she will use the materials in her business-in-a-box (smartphone, solar charging set and weighing scale) to disseminate vital agricultural information to the other members of her village, helping them to improve their crop yields and to increase their incomes.  

With the additional money that she will earn as a CKW, Rehema will support her children. Her biggest dreams include building a nice home and seeing her children receive an education at the university level.

loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone, solar charging set and weighing scale so that she may provide vital farming information to her community.

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is 47 years old and lives in the town of Kintintale in the Kampala South region of Uganda.  She is widowed and has three children, two of whom are currently in school.  Dorothy has been working hard to manage her boutique, in which she sews and sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Dorothy has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase rolls of material for making clothes and will help Dorothy to generate greater profits and be able to save.  Dorothy hopes that in the future she will be able to enlarge her business. 

Dorothy is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Dorothy who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase rolls of material for making clothes.

loans.name: Zulmira

texts.en: Zumira is applying for a loan from Tuba Rai Metin.  This is her first loan and she wants to use it to improve her business.  So, she will use the loan to buy more stock including secondhand clothes, bags and shoes to keep in her shop.  She has been working in her shop for the past few years and has found that this business is very helpful in providing her with an income she can use to survive.

loans.use: to buy secondhand clothes, bags and shoes to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Sevjid

texts.en:
Sevjid is a 40-year-old widow who lives with her son in a ger in Uvs province, Mongolia. Her son, Tsend-Ayush, is a secondary school student who helps his mother to run her business.

Sevjid has been selling organic flour products in the local market for 11 years. She has been importing flour in bulk from Russia but now she is purchasing organic wheat flour from a domestic producer and selling it to local customers at retail.

She is planning to increase her sales of organic wheat flour and is now requesting 1,500,000 MNT to purchase bulk amounts of organic wheat flour from a domestic producer to sell to local customers.

Sevjid is a hardworking and diligent woman who says, "When my son is grown up I want him to be highly educated and able to live by himself, so I started saving my business profits to further his education."

loans.use: to purchase bulk amounts of organic wheat flour from a domestic producer to sell to local customers.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas, aged 42, is a married man and father of four children, ages 12, 7, 4 and 1. He sells fish and also has a spare parts shop in Muhoroni. These businesses have been in operation for a period of over 15 years, earning him a monthly income of 40,000 KES.

He is requesting a third loan of 35,000 KES from KADET, after having successfully repaid his previous loan. He intends to use this amount to purchase a refrigerator for his fish selling business. The profits he earns will go back to his fish business and toward repaying the loan.

Thomas hopes to diversify his business, to start a hotel business and also to educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator for his business.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 27-year-old married man. He describes himself as an intelligent man. Charles operates a retail store where he sells household items. He has been involved in this business for two years.

His business is located within a productive rural area and his primary customers are local residents. Charles identifies his biggest business challenge as insufficient funds for improving the business. He will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy household items.

Charles' business goal is to run a wholesale business within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP Deposit Taking Microfinance Limited.

loans.use: to buy household items to sell.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia opened a kiosk in front of her house one year ago. She started the kiosk with her own working capital of $1,200. She is trying to look for ways to get more working capital to improve her business. 

Now she is taking a loan from TRM (Tuba Rai Meting). She wants to buy additional supplies to keep in her store. She is a busy woman and she hopes, with the effort that she makes, that she will keep her business growing.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, sugar, coffee, and rice.

loans.name: Tsend

texts.en: Tsend is a 54-year-old woman who lives with her husband and daughter in their house in Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband Hohoo, aged 57, has been sick for the last year, stays home and requires constant care. Her daughter Ariunaa, aged 24, graduated university and helps her mother to run her business selling construction supplies in the local construction supplies market. Tsend has been running the business selling construction supplies for the last 3 years. Unfortunately her husband got sick and she needed to take care of him and pay for hospital expenses etc. She stopped her business due to her husband's health issue. Her husband is getting better now and her daughter can take care of her father so she is planning to re-operate her business of selling construction supplies again. She needs an additional investment of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase inventory in order to restart her business. She is a diligent, honest and hardworking woman.

loans.use: to purchase inventory in order to restart her business

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad is a very busy and motivated entrepreneur who has only worked in three jobs that weren’t run by him.  He is always looking for new challenges.

“It’s my passion to do business,” he says. “I like to sell and connect with people. It’s in my blood to do business.” His venture, GM Jewelry Watches, is an eBay.com business that sells brand name, warranty backed watches, which he purchases in bulk directly from the manufacturer.  Originally from Pakistan, Muhammad currently resides in Houston.

In order not to get lost amid the huge number of watches sold on eBay, Muhammad says he takes about 16 photos and leaves a detailed description of each item.  This allows for a better and more thorough online customer experience.

When he first moved to the United States, Muhammad tried selling cars and auto parts and working in the construction business, but didn’t like any of these career paths because they can be slow to return profits.  Then one day he looked into selling watches online and realized he could create a very positive and profitable enterprise. “I sell my watches within three to seven days,” he says. He credits his success to past customers who refer their friends and family members.  He sells about 90 watches a month.

GM Jewelry was launched in early 2012 and, as sales picked up in the first quarter, Muhammad found he needed a loan to purchase more inventory.  In his native country, he had established a good relationship with a bank that worked with small businesses.  With no such contacts in Houston, he started searching online and spoke with various lenders.  He was eventually referred to ACCION Texas Inc.

“I went to Google to find ACCION’s number, called it, and within three to four weeks, I was done,” Muhammad says. 

He plans to pay off this loan within six months and then apply for a larger one.  The loan will make a great difference to his business, he says, because he’ll be able to purchase more inventory, make more sales and earn a larger profit. 

“I was born in a business-oriented family and have 30 years’ experience in business. I’ve always done sales and marketing and I’m very excited with my life.  I praise my God that he has blessed me with good companies like ACCION that guided me every step. This isn’t my first loan, but it is my first loan in America.”

loans.use: to purchase inventory.

loans.name: Ana Elizabeth

texts.en:
Ana Banana’s Snack Shop was established in 2012 by Ana as a snack shop that will provide Mexican and American themed meals and snacks. Her current location in Gardena sells doughnuts and coffee, but Ana wants to expand the menu and market to the nearby schools, churches and parks. She is also hoping to hire two new employees. 

Ana is seeking a $10,000 loan to help her complete the purchase of an existing doughnut shop location.

loans.use: to purchase an existing doughnut shop and expand her menu and market to nearby schools, churches and parks.

loans.name: Tsetsegjargal

texts.en: Tsetsegjargal is 30 years old and lives with her husband and 2 daughters in their house in Niseh district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband Jargalsaihan, age 26, works with her in her business of recyclable waste purchase and sales. Her daughter Morongoo, age 5, goes to the local kindergarten and Maralgoo, age 1, stays home. She and her husband started their business of recyclable waste purchase and sales in 2007 in a spare place on their land. They purchase recyclable waste from local householders and sell to recycling manufacturers for a higher price. They need a car for their business use and she is now requesting 6,500,000 MNT to purchase an eco-friendly, electric and gas consuming car for their business use. She and her husband are responsible, hardworking and open-minded people.

loans.use: to purchase an eco-friendly, electric and gas consuming car for their business use

loans.name: Geser

texts.en:
Geser is 52 years old and lives with his wife and two children. They live in their wooden house in the ger district, an area of the city with no running water, minimal roads and spotty electricity, in Kherlen, the third largest city in Mongolia. His son is studying at the university in Ulaanbaatar city and his daughter is attending secondary school. Geser's wife is a shop assistant at a local company, but a couple of months ago she had an operation on her stomach.  Geser is working as a watchman and working 24 hours. After work he is resting 48 hours and during this time he is running a taxi business in his own car.

He is very thankful to Kiva lenders for helping to expand his living conditions. In the winter, his house passes its heat through the door and gets colder, so they need to use a coal-burning stove to stay warm. The coal burning is becoming the primary source of air pollution in Mongolia, so Geser is requesting 3,000,000 MNT to build a small barn where the house door meets with the outside. By doing this, he can reduce the heat loss in his house, he will burn less coal and his family will live in comfortable conditions.

loans.use: to build a small barn where the house door meets with the outside

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
This is Myrna, 40, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Ernesto and is a mother to her children. She, together with her children, manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide an income for their everyday expenses.  

Myrna operates a junk shop. Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines, and while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic, paper and other materials. They sell these to junk shops for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries like factories and others. Aside from this, she also raises pigs in her compound. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be incorporating the loan into her current revolving fund used to buy trash from collectors. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Myrna hopes to grow her business and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for recyclable materials needed in her business

loans.name: Santina

texts.en:
Santina has five children and two of them are in school. She also has a niece who depends on her. She seems to have a big responsibility for her family, especially for her children's education.

Santina has a kiosk that can generate a good income. She sells hard drinks, soft drinks and biscuits.  She is applying for a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She will use the loan to buy more stock to keep in her store. She is living just nearby the city.

loans.use: to buy hard drinks and soft drinks

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
This is Virginia, She previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and pay her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Virginia hopes to be able to expand her business soon and dreams to give her children a high-quality education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
This is Emma, 43, a resident of Manila, Philippines. Her partner is Inocencio and she is a mother to her children. She, together with her partner, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Emma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHPs-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Emma hopes to expand her business and dreams to give her children a good and quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and where she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and soil to prepare for next year's planting of organic vegetables

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is a 60-year-old married man and a father of a grown up son from Bohol, Philippines. He has engaged in a mat-weaving business for more than 20 years now. This is the source of his income.

Benjamin is asking for a loan to buy materials for mat weaving, such as "romblon," a tropical plant valued for its leaves, and coloring.

Benjamin hopes to make his business successful and sustainable in the future.

loans.use: to buy materials for mat weaving.

loans.name: Hagie

texts.en: Hagie, 33, is married with three kids. She lives in Sebasi, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She cultivates corn to earn a living and she earns 4,000 PHP each month. Hagie requested a loan of 5,500 PHP to purchase fertilizer and seedlings. She has been a member of Kiva's partner, GDMPC, since 2008. In the future, she plans to improve her family's house and live in convenience.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Bienvinida

texts.en:
Bienvinida is a 51-year-old farmer from Ubay, Bohol. She has been engaged in rice farming business together with her husband for more than 10 years now. 

Bienvinida works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of the family, especially for the schooling of her children. Bienvinida is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm. With this, she and her husband will be able to grow and produce a good harvest from the farm.

In the future, Bienvinida hopes to expand her family business in the future. She also wants to save money to reinvest in that business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita is a 47-year old married woman with 7 children living in Tinacla-an, Clarin. In order to increase her family's income, she entered into a buying and selling business which she started 8 years ago. She usually gets 5,000 PHP per month. With the help of GDMPC microcredit, Teresita will be able to buy products to sell with the 8,000 PHP loan rendered to her. She joined GDMPC in 2011. Someday, she’s hoping for much greater revenue that she will use to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy products to sell

loans.name: Angelica

texts.en:
Angelica knew she needed to find work in her new home after moving from Durango, Mexico to El Paso, Texas. She debated on what would best suit her lifestyle and then decided to return to retail. 

She ultimately decided to put her 20 years of experience in that industry to work to start her own business:  Life Time Watch, a store where she sells new watches purchased at wholesale. The five-year-old business only carries the latest styles, Angelica says. Currently, she employees two people, but Angelica plans to hire more as her business expands. 

Angelica’s daughter, a student at St. Mary’s University, found out about Accion Texas Inc. and encouraged her to apply for a loan. Upon approval, Angelica used the loan to purchase inventory for the holiday season.

loans.use: to purchase inventory.

loans.name: Jimmy

texts.en:
Jimmy is 40 years old. He is married and has three children. He runs his mobile money transfer and auto spare parts businesses in his hometown of Lundazi, a town in eastern Zambia near the border with Malawi.

Jimmy has been selling car spare parts for five years now. He added mobile money transfers to his line of business two years ago.  Being a Zoona mobile money transfer agent means that Jimmy offers the service of sending and receiving money to his community. He gets his profit every time a customer uses the service at his shop. He says being a Zoona mobile money transfers agent has helped him grow as a businessman in his town. When asked what his biggest challenge is, he sites the lack of working capital. He says the saddest part is that, when he runs out of cash at his shop, he has to make his customers wait, while he goes out to look for money and in some cases ends business..

He is grateful for the opportunity to get a Kiva loan, as it will help boost his working capital and he will earn more profit. He thanks the Kiva lenders.

In this video, a representative from Zoona interviews Jimmy.

loans.use: To increase his cash on hand to make more money transfers

loans.name: Maria Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina previously received a 12,000 PHP loan that was used to buy spare parts, accessories and maintenance for their tricycle unit. Her earnings were a big help in the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and  maintenance for their tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Edwina hopes to be able to buy another tricycle. She dreams that her children will finish college. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts and maintenance for her tricycle.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia's main source of income comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. She is 57 years old, married and has children. She is from Gala village in Ozamis City, and has been farming for 15 years, earning an amount of 11,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Virginia joined GDMPC. Virginia is requesting a loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
This is Melinda. She previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts and accessories, and to pay for the maintenance of her jeepney unit. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan to buy  spare parts and accessories, and to pay for the maintenance of her jeepney unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her family's daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Melinda dreams that her children will finish their education. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for accessories, spare parts and for the maintenance of her jeepney service

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en: Narcisa is married with 3 children. She is 54 years old and lives in the Sebasi village of Clarin, in Misamis Occidental. Narcisa plants, harvests and sells corn to earn a living. She has had this business for 10 years. Each month, she earns 6,000 PHP. She has requested a loan of 9,500 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She has been a member of GDMPC since 2008. In the future, Narcisa hopes to expand and improve her business to support her family's daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Armelinda

texts.en: Armelinda is 55 years old and married. She is from Minsubong, Tangub City. She has three grown children who have helped her to take care of their coconuts. They have been working at this business 20 years and earn 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Armelinda joined GDMPC. She has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer pay for weeding costs. She hopes to have a bountiful harvest and to expand her cultivated area.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pay for weeding

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en: Jerry is 48 years old and married. He was three children and lives in Sebasi Clarin, Philippines. Jerry manages and cultivates a corn farm as his main source of income. Jerry earns PHP 5,000 every month with this work. He has requested a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy fertilizers, such as manure. Jerry has been a member of GDMPC since 2008. His future plan is to see his children finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar is a 57 year old resident of  Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Divina, and together they manage their household while operating their business. He  works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Edgar operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. He makes a profit by purchasing his supplies at wholesale prices and then sells them by the piece. His store is located adjacent to his house. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 350 PHP in sales every day.

To help him continue the operation of his business, he is requesting a 32,000 PHP loan. He will buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 

Edgar hopes to expand soon and dreams of continuing his youngest child’s education. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell in his business.

loans.name: Enebish

texts.en: Enebish is 52 years old and single. He lives with his granddaughter in her parent’s apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital. His granddaughter, 22, is a student whose parents have been working in Korea as contract workers for 10 years. Enebish sells home furnishings and mathematics books that are used in schools with additional training. He was a professional mathematics teacher. Initially, Enebish started his business in the 1990s while the Socialist era was collapsing. It was a rough time. The government didn’t have a money to pay for social servants and reduced the number of employees like teachers, militants, doctors and nurses. Therefore, many people used to do businesses and Enebish is one of them. The loan Enebish is taking will be used to increase his business capital to purchase a large amount of books and furnishings from Russia. Now Enebish buys his products from an intermediary. As a Soviet student, Enebish speaks fluently in Russian, so he won't have any problems with his business trip to Russia.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of books and furnishings to sell

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
This is Agustina, 64, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is a widow and a mother to her children. She manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Agustina operates a food stall. She sells snacks like banana cue (sugar coated banana), kamote cue (sugar coated sweet potato) and suman (Filipino rice cake steamed in banana leaves) in their community. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy ingredients like bananas, sweet potatoes, sugar and other ingredients needed in her product. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Agustina hopes to have a strong body to continuously provide for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like bananas, sweet potatoes, sugar and other ingredients

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna is 48 years old and married, with 11 children. She's from Sebasi, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. To make a living, Myrna grows corn. Myrna has been engaged in her business for 15 years and earns PHP 2,500 a month. Myrna joined GDMPC in 2008. She is requesting a loan of PHP 3,500 to buy seedlings and fertilizer, such as manure. Myrna will use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Dominguita

texts.en:
This is Dominguita. She is 66 and is a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Francisco, and she is a mother to her children. Together with her partner, she manages their household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Dominguita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages to the local neighbourhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She makes a profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue to operation her business, she is requesting loan of PHP 10,000. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Dominguita hopes to live according to the will of God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages for her business.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
This is Letecia, 41, a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Joel, a welder, and she is a mother to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  
Letecia operates an apartment rental business. The apartment is rented on a monthly basis. She earns a minimum of 3200 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in rentals every week.
To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 30,000. She will be utilizing the loan for the repair and maintenance of her apartment for rent. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  
Letecia dreams to be able to add more business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for repair and maintenance of her rental apartment.

loans.name: Eduvigis

texts.en: Eduvigis is a 62-year-old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She and her husband have been rice farmers for more than 10 years now. This is the source of their income. Eduvigis believes that she can improve their livelihood through hard work and perseverance. She is also thankful that CEVI is around to provide financial services to microentrepreneurs like her. Eduvigis is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and pesticides. With the loan, she will be able to expand their rice farming business and improve their harvest and yield.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and pesticides

loans.name: Tsevegmid

texts.en:
Mrs.Tsevegmid is a 48 year-old woman who lives with her husband and daughter in a ger in the Uvs province of Mongolia. Her husband Dorligsuren, 52, grows, harvests and sells organic vegetables. Her daughter Bolortuya, age 23, has graduated from the university and is now looking for job. 

Tsevegmid has been working as an assistant chef/chef for a number of cafeterias since 1998. She is now just starting her own cafeteria in the center of the province, where most of the population lives. Her husband supplies organic vegetables for her cafe; he stores organic vegetables in their storage pit and sells them during the winter and spring. 

She is now requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase a large amount of seeds and soil to prepare next year's planting for her husband's agriculture business. The borrower and her husband are both hardworking and responsible people.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of seeds and soil to prepare next year's planting for her husband's agriculture business.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.ru:
Валентина замужем, имеет двоих детей. Муж Валентины работает на стройке, а она занимается выращиванием овощей в теплицах уже на протяжении 16 лет. В основном выращивает огурцы и помидоры. В прошлом сезоне урожай был меньше обычного из-за болезней помидоров. Поэтому в этом году Валентина решила купить более дорогие семена и провести отопление в теплицах. Для этого ей нужен кредит в размере 6,000 гривен. На следующий год Валентина с мужем надеется расширить свой бизнес и построить еще две большие теплицы, т.к. у них есть свободный участок земли.

На фото: Валентина со своим мужем.
texts.en:
Valentina is married and she has two children.  While Valentina's husband works in construction, she has been cultivating vegetables in greenhouses for the past 16 years.  She mainly grows cucumbers and tomatoes.  Last season's crop yield was less than usual due to a tomato disease.  This is why Valentina has decided to buy more expensive tomato seeds this year and to supply heat to her greenhouses.  To do so she needs a loan of 6,000 hryvnia.  Next year, Valentina and her husband would like to further expand their business and build two large greenhouses, as they have some extra land.

In the photo:  Valentina and her husband.

loans.use: to buy tomato seeds and supply heat to her greenhouses.

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
This is Amelita, 56, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Edgardo, a driver, and is mother to her three children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Amelita operates a peanut butter making business. What she basically does is buy raw peanuts and other ingredients needed in making her product from the market, process it then repacked them and sell them per piece to individuals, general store owners and the local community. Peanut butter is repacked in 250 and 500 grams plastic bottle. She also sells accessories for additional income. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy additional stock of raw ingredients used in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Amelita dreams of expanding her business and hopes to have her own house and lot through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have a growing network of customers. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like peanuts, sugar, oil, margarine, etc

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en: Tuya is 51 years old and lives with her husband, daughter and granddaughter in an apartment in Mongolia's Govi-Altai province. Her husband Batsuh, 55, stays home taking care of their granddaughter Indranil, who is 2. Her daughter, Sainzaya, is 24 years old and has just graduated from a hair-dressing course. Now, Sainzaya is starting her own barbershop business in her mother's barbershop and needs to purchase a chair and other necessary equipment to start her business. Tuya is now requesting loan of 3500000 MNT to purchase her daughter a hair-dressing chair and other equipment and tools. Her family has warm, friendly and hardworking people.

loans.use: to purchase her daughter a hair dressing chair and other equipment and tools.

loans.name: Sayvali

texts.ru: Сайвали проживает в городе Куляб. Ему 61 год. Он женат. У него пятеро детей. Сайвали на протяжении тридцати лет работает преподавателем. Кроме того он занимается животноводством. В этой области он десять лет. Сайвали разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. Он берет кредит для закупа бычков.
texts.en:
Sayvali lives in the city of Kulob.  He is 61 years old, married, and has five children.  He has been working as a  teacher for thirty years.  In addition, he is also involved in animal husbandry.  

Sayvali has been living in this region for ten years, raising cattle at home.  He is taking a loan to buy young bulls.

loans.use: to buy young bulls.

loans.name: Valeriy

texts.ru: Валерий занимается выращиванием овощей в теплицах более 10 лет. Он уже пользовался бизнес кредитом, благодаря которому в прошлом сезоне смог провести отопление в двух теплицах и сохранить свой урожай от весенних морозов. В этот раз кредит нужен для закупки семян и удобрений. Этот бизнес - основной источник дохода Валерия и его семьи. В планах Валерия - расширение своего участка и постройка дополнительных теплиц.
texts.en: Valeriy has been cultivating vegetables in greenhouses for more than ten years.  His previous loan, last season, allowed him to supply heat to two of his greenhouses and to protect his crop from spring frosts.  This time, he needs a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers.  Valeriy's business is his family's main source of income.  His future plans involve getting more land and building additional greenhouses.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Alikhon

texts.ru: Алихон проживает в районе Хамадони. Ему 35 лет. Он женат. У него трое детей. Алихон занимается торговлей. Он арендует торговую точку на центральном рынке района. Алихон занимается торговлей хозяйственных и канцелярских товаров.  В этой области он два года. Алихон берет кредит для покупки канцелярских товаров.
texts.en: Alikhon lives in the Hamadoni region.  He is 35 years old, married, and has three children.  He is involved in retail business and rents an outlet at the local central market.  He sells household goods and office supplies.  He has been working in this field for two years.  He is taking a loan to buy office supplies.

loans.use: to buy office supplies.

loans.name: Abdilgozi

texts.ru: Абдилгози проживает в районе Яван. Ему 57 лет. Он женат. У него пятеро детей. Абдилгози преподаватель. В этой области он работает 20 лет. Кроме того Абдилгози занимается посевом сельскохозяйственных культур. В этой области он шесть лет. Абдилгози берет кредит для закупа минеральных удобрений, топлива и семян.
texts.en: Abdilgozi lives in the Yavan district.  He is 57 years old, married, and has five children.  He is a teacher and has been working in this field for 20 years.  Additionally, he sows field crops and has been involved in this activity for six years.  He is taking a loan to buy mineral fertilizers, fuel and seeds.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizers, fuel and seeds.

loans.name: Estella

texts.en:
Estella is a merchant from Bohol, Philippines. She earns a living through her sari-sari (variety store business) selling various goods to the people in her locality.

Estella is asking for a loan to buy additional stock to sell such as dry goods, canned goods, snack foods and chips, sodas, toiletries and others. With this loan, she will be able to enhance her stocks thus allowing her to attract and cater to more customers and buyers in her store. In the future, Estella hopes to expand her business and save money for future use and expenses.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell, such as dry goods, canned goods, snack foods and chips, sodas, toiletries and others

loans.name: Tseveldulam

texts.en:
Tseveldulam is 49 years old, and lives with her husband and son in Ger (a traditional yurt) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her husband  Bold is aged 55 and works in a private construction company as a taskmaster. Her son Davaadagva is 23 years old, has graduated university and is looking for a job now. She has been working as saleswoman at a rental counter of the local market since 2000. She has built a close relationship with customers and suppliers over the years. 

Tseveldulam is now planning to start her own business of a butcher shop at the local market. She is requesting 3'900'000MNT to purchase meat at a wholesale price from herders to sell it to both local customers at a retail price and companies producing meat products at a higher price than wholesale.

Tseveldulam is a friendly, communicative and hard working person.

loans.use: to purchase meat at a wholesale price from herders to sell

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
This is Clarita. She previously accessed an 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase greater quantities and more varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and in their personal, house hold, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profits, and her business profits will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Clarita hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell

loans.name: Khuderbaatar

texts.en:
Khuderbaatar is 27 years old, and lives with his wife and 3-year-old daughter in their recently bought 32-square-meter apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His colleagues describe him as a smart, honest, hard-working and reliable guy that can perform any task relating to the factory he works in at any time. 

In 2004 he started his working career as a mechanic in an ice-cream making company. His wife works as a technologist at the same company. Now Khuderbaatar works as a manager. He realized that as he keeps working hard, his life has been changed and many surprising things have occurred. As a young married couple they have solved their housing problem by taking mortgage loan - before this they used to rent a house. Khuderbaatar is requesting a loan to buy furniture like double bed, wardrobe and electrical appliances to decorate their apartment with no appliances. By doing this Khuderbaatar’s family can improve their living condition.

loans.use: to buy furniture

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
This is Rebecca, 42, and a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Alberto, who is a mason, and she is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rebecca operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Rebecca hopes to give her children a good and quality education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for convenience store stock items needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy used clothes to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more recyclable materials to resell.

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando is a 45-year-old married man and a father of two young children. He is from Ubay, Bohol. He has been engaged in a fish vending business for several years now. Fernando is asking for a loan to buy more fish to sell to the people in his area.

Fernando works hard to support his family especially for the schooling of his two children. He dreams of making his business a success in the future and supports his children in their schooling.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To repair the body and maintain the engine of a rickshaw

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Kuvat

texts.ru: Куват проживает в Яванском районе. Ему 60 лет. Он женат. У него шестеро детей. Куват вместе с женой занимается растениеводством. Он в основном выращивает бобовые культуры и овощи. В этой области Куват пять лет. Он берет кредит для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Kuvat lives in the Yavan region of Tajikistan. He is 60 years old, married, and has six children. Kuvat and his wife are farmers and grow mainly legumes and vegetables. Kuvat has been engaged in this activity for five years. He is taking this loan to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es:
Marlene, de 64 años, es una mujer muy buena y amable, está casada con Jorge y fruto de su matrimonio tiene 6 hijos que ya son mayores e independientes, vive en su casa propia junto a 5 hijos de los cuales brinda mayor atención a su última hija de 15 años, ya que los demás generan sus propios ingresos. 
El trabajo de Marlene, consiste en la venta de comida, instala sus mesas y sillas en la vereda de su casa en donde ofrece a la venta gran variedad de potajes regionales como “cecina con tacacho”, “juane”, “pescado ahumado”, chorizos y otros. Lleva realizando esta actividad desde hace 2 años y trabaja con la ayuda de sus hijos quienes le brindan el apoyo necesario para que todo siempre le vaya bien. Le gusta mucho su trabajo, pues esta en contacto con las personas, se divierte, se relaja y sobre todo genera ingresos económicos para su hogar, de esta forma puede darle lo necesario a su menor hija, algunas veces lleva pedidos a domicilio y siempre tiene clientes que le solicitan sus deliciosos potajes, le esta yendo bien y espera mas adelante poder poner un restaurante ya que tiene muchas expectativas en su negocio. Por ello solicita 3500 soles, para comprar ingredientes e insumos como arroz, carnes, condimentos, aceite, y verduras para seguir con la preparación de sus deliciosos platillos, además comprará ollas y otros utensilios que necesitan renovación.
texts.en:
Marlene, age 64, is a good-natured and kind woman. She is married to Jorge and they have six children who are grown and independent. Marlene lives in her own home with five of her children, but most of her attention is focused on her youngest daughter (age 15) since the others earn their own income.

Marlene’s work consists of selling food. She has tables and chairs set up along the pavement in front of her house. Marlene offers a wide variety of regional dishes such as “cecina con tacacho” (plantain fritters with pork), “juanes” (chicken and rice steamed in banana leaves), smoked fish, chorizo sausage, and other items. She has been in business for two years and works with the support of her children, who help out when necessary so that everything is always running well. Marlene enjoys her work because she likes being in contact with other people. She also finds the work relaxing, but most of all it gives her a way to generate household income so that she can provide whatever her youngest daughter needs. Sometimes Marlene will make home deliveries, but her customers are always requesting her delicious dishes. She is doing well and hopes to open a restaurant later on since she has high expectations for her business.

Marlene is requesting a loan of 3,500 PEN so that she can buy ingredients and supplies such as rice, meats, condiments, oil, and vegetables in order to continue preparing her delicious dishes. In addition, she will buy pots and other utensils since her existing ones need to be replaced.

loans.use: to buy rice, meats, condiments, oil, vegetables, pots, and utensils.

loans.name: Sharif
